And we're back for the second episode
of 'All in the Field: AWS Agriculture Live.'

All right, we have
the first of our four agriculture episodes that are focused on startups.

And so we had a lot of fun planning
and prepping for this episode. We've learned a lot,
and we hope that you enjoy

hearing all about the startups
that are active in Agriculture.
Welcome to 'AWS All in the Field.'

I'm Rachel Bradshaw,
a go-to Market Specialist for IoT and Agriculture. If you joined us last week,
you met me already,

but just to remind everyone,
I'm based in Seattle, Washington. I'm a passionate advocate for IoT,
agriculture, and startups.

And we're going to be talking about
pieces of all three of those passions today, so I'm super excited.

Also, if you joined us on the last show,
you recalled, how much we like to stay apprised
of the latest in technology and food.

And we will be talking a little bit about both
today so... excited about that.

And as always,
I'm joined by my partner-in-crime, Karen. I feel like one day
we're going to like actually get in trouble

for doing a crime together,
and then we'll come back to this episode. But my name is Karen Hildebrand,

and I am our Worldwide Head of Solutions Architecture
for the agriculture industry.

And, so I have been in agriculture
my whole life. I grew up in a farm, fourth generation,
and have done a lot of my education

related to machine learning
and artificial intelligence. So we talk a lot about this, Rachel, but I am so excited
that AWS is in the agriculture space

and is providing the backbone
for a lot of really innovative applications

that are pushing the boundaries
of what's possible. And so today,
we should head over to our field notes.

And we'll get started on telling you
about some of the cool things that we're seeing and sharing with you
what's new in Ag.

Rachel, let's start our lightning round. We're going to go today
around the globe in agriculture,

and we're going to talk about startups
what they're building and why.

That's right. And today, we're starting in Halifax,
Nova Scotia, Canada. We're talking about Perennia,
who built a cost of production application.

And Perennia food and agriculture
recognize that there was a challenge that the agriculture industry faced,

and that was having a clear understanding
of their costs of production. So they decided
to do something about it.

fuel sensors, GPS tracking,
and water monitoring. And at a high level, it enables the user
to see the actual spend

against that usage all in one place, whether it be on a computer,
or a smartphone, or a tablet,

and you're able to analyze reports
and make intelligent business decisions based on the information displayed.

And you can receive alerts
if anything seems amiss. So super cool. Where are we going next, Karen?

Let's head over to Amsterdam
in the Netherlands. And, as we journey across our globe here,

we are going to talk about 30MHz. And what 30MHz has done
is really address some of the big challenges
in agriculture around connectivity and understanding how to persist data on the edge.

So they've built hardware devices and are using IoT Core
and IoT Greengrass
in order to connect those devices and ensure that they have persistence.

and we worked with them in partnership
and helping them to make sure that none of that data would be lost.

They're using LoRa networks
for connectivity, which is a great pattern
that we're seeing

in rural and remote environments. And so they've been able
to really help understand

indoor growing environments,
make that data available and have a control plane that assists
within the growing of specialty crops.
So where are we off to next, Rachel? Hinakura, New Zealand, with RiverWatch.
Hopefully, I pronounced that right. I was practicing, I'm not going to lie. But RiverWatch is protecting the environment.

They understand that the importance of data
for monitoring the health of the natural environment was such an inspiration
initially, that they're now actually putting into place

as a startup, by using waterborne drones to monitor the quality
of New Zealand's inland waterways.

You know, RiverWatch founder, James Muir,
came up with this idea after seeing the health of a river
near his father's farm,

deteriorate due to unsound farming practices
further upstream.

And he realized that they need to collect
more data to show government stakeholders and encourage landowners
and farmers and community groups

to take their own action
to improve waterways, was super important. So it spurred this idea
of a real time monitor

that you can have anchored in the river
that sends data consistently back to you, so that you always know
what's happening in the water.

And it debuted its prototype
floating river drone in 2019. And they were submerged

with interest from quite a few people. And they were able to incorporate
low-cost sensors that monitor
a variety of factors relating to river health, such as oxygen levels, turbidity,
and water temperature, so super cool. And what's next?
I was going to say that is really cool. I get really excited when I see things, especially when it's like a submersible,

it looks like a little mini submarine. So it's pretty cool. So we're going to head actually off the Israel,
staying in the submersible space.

And we're going to talk about GiliOcean
who's got a GO Smart technology

that they have developed. And it is specific for aquaculture. So understanding, using computer vision
and a underwater camera,
how to do biomass detection. And so this is a really interesting segue,

actually goes really nicely
into our upcoming episode. Next episode is all going to be
about Computer Vision.

So just a little call-out to put October 1
on your calendar as well. 'Cause we will be talking about
how Computer Vision can be used in agriculture.

And in this particular case,
it's being used to help with biomass detection. So understanding the fish
that are in the pen

as well as understanding
the potential biomass; but indicating if there's any concerns to health,
or if there's any actions
that need to be taken around fish and how the stock is doing at any given time.

So back to you. Your turn, Rachel. Yeah, we're going all the way back to Vancouver,
British Columbia, back in Canada,

with Semios, which does pest detection. And I talked a little bit about this last week
because I think it's super cool,

where they've built this IoT-based AgTech solution. And they offer a few different solutions,
but at its simplest,

they provide growers' data on climate
and pests and diseases in their orchards. And so these IoT boxes
are equipped with sensors

and cameras to monitor
for different types of insects and can deploy pheromones to attract
and trap the insect that it detects.

It also has... Or some of their devices have capability
to identify the pests and, if need be,

only spray the chemical that's needed
and at the minimum level needed so that you're not just
spraying the entire crop.

And, you know,
that's impactful to the environment. These devices also forecast both pests
and disease activity, as I mentioned.

They're able to automate moisture tracking
and management. There's frost alerts on it,
it saves growers money

and it protects their yield. So super, super exciting. And I think we have
a few other questions here.

So I think, Rachel,
you're going to have an opinion on this one. From Alexsmasha.

That's a good thing.
It wasn't a bad thing. "Is IoT going to change food habits
and make the human diet healthier?"

Yeah, I mean, we definitely see it
impacting the way food habits are...

I'd rather say, "Yes,
it is changing food habits." It's helping with increased yields.

It's helping expand crops
as people look to do more controlled environment agriculture
and therefore making food

more accessible across the globe. And in some cases, even slightly cheaper
because when you have a greater yield,

you're able to reduce costs at times
and using IoT to improve efficiencies across your farm and save money.

You know, a lot of times

there's definitely a chance

it will help make human diets healthier. That said, people like what they like,
so they will eat what they want to eat.

So maybe our end goal here
is actually to enable people to have choice in what they want to eat
as opposed to helping them be healthier.
Yes. That's right. You have the option to be healthy if you want to be.

I think that's a fair point. - Okay.
- Okay, right on. French fries are potatoes too, right, so...

You got it. Excellent. So I think we are going to move on
to our next guest.

And we are going to go ahead
and welcome in, from the United States, Steve Valencsin,
who is the Founder and CEO of Growers, and he is joining us today from North Carolina.

Hey. Hey, Rachel, Karen.
How are you, guys? Hi, Steven. Good. Thanks for having me on the show.

So, you probably tell the story
better than any of us could introduce you, but would you mind telling us

how your story in agriculture has gone? And what brought you now
to where you are with Growers?
Yeah, no, good question. It's been a quite a journey. And, you know, it's an interesting story.

So yeah, I started Growers about 10 years ago but really been involved
in agriculture my entire life.

So, it's not a new concept,
but we've been working

on trying to build technology
to help connect farmers and their advisors. And we started as a services business
actually being the advisor to farmers.

And so we're coming
from a position of empathy and understanding.
And the fact that I,

you know, grew up farming
and actually still farm a little bit on my own, I think puts us in a pretty good spot
to understand at least both sides

of the equation,
both from the farmer and the advisor. And that's the learning that we took
and applied it to the technology

that we're building today. So yeah, Growers is a company
based out of Raleigh, Durham, North Carolina, and we're servicing farmers
pretty much all across North America now.

All right, so one minute pitch, what is the kind of three biggest problems
that Growers solves as a as a platform?

Yeah, well, so I think
you got to kind of understand maybe like the current state of the problem.

And that like there's a lot of technology
that's on the market today; unfortunately, what we found
is is that it all seems to be

a little bit rearward looking. And what farmers really need
is like data and technology

that can be actionable and timely
and help them make better decisions on how to go forward. And that was like kind of our chief thing
that we discovered

when we were the advisor.
Like, Karen, you can appreciate this, right, is that farmers are optimists, right? And they're always looking forward,

but all the technology and data analytics
and dashboards and reports today like have this rearward view look.

And so we built a tool that helps aggregate
a bunch of really important data from soils and sensors and machines,

as well as financial information, consolidate that into one platform, and then allow an advisor
and a farmer to execute on it quickly,

primarily around the decisions
that they need to make for seed, fertilizer, and chemical recommendations.

We focus on those three
because they're the ones that, accurate data, I think can drive the best impact
or the highest overall impact

when it comes to a ROI standpoint. And that's what we've been focused on
for about two and a half years now.

And now we're spending a little bit more time
working with Ag retailers and trying to help them
kind of consolidate their sales planning process

and talk about positioning their products
more appropriately and using data
to help drive those decisions now.

Can we dive into that a little further? I love that it aggregates
and combines, you said seed, chemical, and fertilizer,

but can we dive a little further? How does it actually integrate
those three sources? How are you able to do that?

Yeah, so today, we're doing it
inside of our AWS environment,

but we're like taking information
from various different soil like soil testing laboratories.
So like data that's take from...

..excuse me, taken from labs,
analyzed into the cloud. And then once it's in the cloud,
we're pulling that information down

and combining that back
with like the exact, you know, spatial location
that the samples were taken.

Then we're integrating machinery data
from like my John Deere and climate and all of the,

you know, actual physical equipment
that's in the field. and then we're layering in financial data, And then we have a few kind of key data points
on our platform

that are actually user-entered. One of the really cool things
about our product is that it's... We call it a zero data entry technology

because it really only lets you
enter three digits. And usually those have to do
with adjusting your prices.

And so that's been a really big feature
for farmers and for agronomists
'cause like nobody wants to spend a bunch of time

doing data entry.
And I certainly didn't, and that's why we built the tool
in the way that we did is, I hate it.

I hate doing data entry. So we've had a lot of luck
with that functionality.

I would love to know the person
or the farmer that says, "You know what,
I'd really like to do data entry instead."
So I think that... No, they don't exist. I don't think...
Well, it's funny because like I... We're in the chat. Yeah. Yeah.

Yeah. No, I think that
that makes a lot of sense. And I think you mentioned
a number of other platforms.

How did you find the scene
that was the right scene for Growers, and then not only you found it
but you have really transitioned to,

you know, a serverless architecture, you're using some pretty
state-of-the-art services,
and really a lot of geospatial processing. How did you find that scene?

And what kind of services
are you using it to enable Growers?

Yeah, that's a great question. You know, I think we, you know,
found it by experiencing

kind of, all of the pain and heartache,
you know, ourselves. And especially myself, like, you know,

I tell the story all the time
of like a time I was combining, you know, soy beans
in our farm in North Carolina,

and there was like this hurricane coming in. And, I like literally didn't care about anything
other than getting the beans out

and my yield monitor quit working. And so like, it wasn't recording any data
and like, didn't care, but then like the whole time, I'm like, kicking myself.

'Cause I felt like a hypocrite, right,
for not actually capturing this information. And so it was like, that's kind of
how we like figured out that like,

Hey, there's an opportunity here
that we need to build more simplified technology. So that like problems like this
aren't actually problems,
and that there's so much value in that data that like, I would have stopped anything, right, even for a hurricane to capture it.

So like, we took that understanding
and then, you know, like you said, integrated it that the complexity of it
was like trying to find out

how do you make spatial data
and all of this information come together. That's been a kind of a crazy journey for us.

And like what you're showing here
on the screen is like what we found is that a lot of the technology
that AWS was offering us,

it was really kind of key
to helping us connect those dots. And make those connections actually possible,

and doing that within a timeframe
that matters, right? Like latency is a real big issue in agriculture.

And again, like for information
to be valuable, we think it has to be timely,
it has to be accurate.

And that's really hard to do. It's really hard to pull that information
through any data pipeline.

And we found, you know,
some of the best solutions inside the AWS toolkit, and using things
like Lambda and even Redshift

for some of the analysis
and the data processing  that we're doing. Ultimately trying to deliver a,

you know, the most accurate data possible
to an advisor in the quickest manner possible
and with as few human touch points as possible.

That's great. So I have to ask too,
because you're talking about human touch points, especially at AWS, we are so customer obsessed.

How do you continue to innovate
and make sure that you're getting feedback from Growers on your platform
so that you're staying ahead of the game?
Yeah, that's a good question. It takes a lot of effort. And like you have to be intentional about it.

And so we've been, you know,
in this business for 10 years. And have like experienced,
you know, ton of growth

that we've been really blessed with.
But it's like, I've seen this like curve of our product development

and really like the value
that we can deliver to customers. And it correlates exactly
with the amount of time

we've invested in collecting customer feedback, right? When we first started,
we were obsessed as well.

And like probably annoyingly obsessed
with pestering our customers around like,

"What do you think about this?
What about this? What if we did that? How about this?
Do you like that? Why not?" And it really showed
in the first launch of our product,

and we got, you know,
really, really high adoption very, very quickly. And it completely,
like overwhelmed our entire system,

which is coincidentally why we're, you know, have entirely rebuilt it.
Is that we got enough demand

that we actually, our architecture
and our technology couldn't support it. But yeah, back to the customer point,

is then we got really busy
and we started to kind of slip, and then like you start to see
that lack of customer touch points

or lack of customer feedback,
start to impact the product. And, you know, I think any business, especially small businesses
and startups are faced with this.

Is like you think you're hiring
a bunch of really smart people that have like a bunch of great ideas, and those great ideas
are making their way into your product.

The reality of it is like, nobody's ever going to be
smarter than your customer, including your employees.

They're just the ones responsible for, you know, articulating
what your customer wants into, you know, computer code and engineering architecture
to make it a reality.

And so when we got back on track
and like became obsessed with making sure
that we're constantly capturing

that customer feedback,
it shows in the product. I mean, we just did a demo
for a new product we're launching in November

with an ad retailer.
And one of the first things that he told us after we did the demo with him was like,
"Wow, I can tell you really listened to my feedback." We're like, "Yes. Yes, we did."

I was going to say
that is the perfect thing to hear. And, you know,
I think that's actually something

that's pretty unique about what Growers
has done is how you really move from startup to being able to scale.

So, how have you worked
with some of those, you know, larger Ag retailers
who are using your platform?

How have you figured out to go from, you know, startup - good idea,
to making sure that it's,
you know, available broadly in the market? Yeah, that's good question.

I think it's like kind of connected
to the customer feedback one. Is that agriculture is such a complex space.
And it's got such a mix of characters from, you know, all of the players that are in here,

that there's like so many problems
in so many different areas. And like, everybody needs help,
you know, and ourselves included.

And I think it was this like connection
that we had to, you know, the boots on the ground.

Like actually being a farmer
and being an advisor and having to work with Ag retailers
and insurance agents and bankers,

and like all of the relationships
that are in agriculture. I think it enabled us
like when we approached,

'cause like we understand
part of that complexity. And one of the things
that we've always been pretty keen on

is like we're not trying to boil the ocean
and solve everybody's problems all at once.

We've been trying to be laser-focused
on finding like, what's that one unique pain point
and then just perfecting that, right?

So for our very first product, it was variable rate
seed fertilizer prescriptions, that's it.

Like that we could do nothing else. But we figured out
how to do that in like, you know, 100 times faster
than any other product in the market.

And that gave us the adoption and allowed us
to expand into a bunch of other features. So I think it's, you know,
finding that problem

and being relatable has really opened up
a lot of opportunities. In a bunch of different industries
that are starting to get a little bit further away

Which has been super exciting
'cause we're just, again, finding out how fantastically complicated
this industry called Agriculture is.

That's right. You talk about mix of characters, Karen and I
always consider ourselves a mix of characters,

and we definitely need help. - One more question for you.
- Yeah, absolutely.

What are the key insights
you would share with other startups when choosing a technology partner? Like what are the lessons learned
if you were to give guidance to others?

Yeah, no, that's a good question. I feel like, we've... The only things we've done right so far
because we did them wrong the first time.

And so, you know, I think, I don't know, if there's another way you can learn things,
but if there are, you know, please tell me

'cause that seems to be
the only way we learn anything. You know, yeah, so scalability and flexibility,

I think, are the two, like, key words
that our engineering team and our product team are focused on,

you know, this year. And I think those
are the, you know, looking back, you know, in the past four or five years, as we've been doing this is understanding

what these like short-term compromises
that all small companies and startups have to make in order to,

you know, hit revenue goals
and keep investors happy and satisfy customers. You're making,
like, it's just compromise

after compromise after compromise. And usually, the first thing to go,
right, is that, like,

we're going to build a solution
that maybe won't be as scalable and maybe won't be as flexible,
but we'll come back and try to address it later.

And I think those are situations and decisions
that need to be extremely well thought out

because the long-term implications
for those are extremely expensive. And then the last thing I'll say is choosing,

you know, a partner in the space. You know, this is probably a good forum
to talk about,

you know, the kind of the evolution
that our business kind of did with AWS. When I got introduced
to the worldwide business development lead

for agriculture, and then actually, Karen,
he introduced me to you. I remember like the lessening of...

feeling a lot less anxiety,
trying to talk with the AWS team about solutions for agriculture.
Because you guys and your team

like actually understood what it was
that we were talking about. Which is unique
because I think I've said the complexity of agriculture

probably like 10 times since we started,
but it really is like that. And it's hard to explain that
to somebody else.

And so, you guys were able
to put us in contact, well, actually to backup,
I remember the first question that...

And he's like, "Well, we need to change that." And so he put me in contact
with our current Account Manager,

a woman named Beth
and we have a Solutions Architect named Cullen. And they like immediately
seem to almost take,

you know, ownership of the challenges
and the problems that we're having and have been really instrumental
in kind of connecting us

with a bunch of, you know,
AWS partners. We're working with a firm called Pariveda

solving some of these challenges. And that was all facilitated through,
you know, our Account Manager.

And then on top of that, you know,
some of the AWS, like the Kick-starter programs and the Activate programs
that we've been able to be involved in

have really helped, you know,
kind of spearhead some of these decisions around,

you know, doing migrations, right.
'Cause we were in dual environments, from a cloud storage standpoint
and having to make that shift is,

"Well, I think I'd probably rather

you know, makes it a little less scary, as well as just the infinite amount of resources
that we seem to have.

So, you know, again,
we made that decision wrong the first time and, you know, we paid for it dearly.

So choosing a technology partner
and providers that understand the business that you're in and are willing to spend time
understanding that

I think it has been a really big deal for us. And one of the kind of key success factors,
I think, as you think about our current tech stack.

Yes, full of fun things to do,

the dollar sign into our UI. And so when the first person
